com.beaglebuddy.mp3
Class MP3

java.lang.Object
  com.beaglebuddy.mp3.MP3Base
      com.beaglebuddy.mp3.MP3

public class MP3
extends MP3Base

This class provides high level, easy to use functions for working with .mp3 files. In particular, it provides a simple, easy to use yet powerful interface for getting and setting information about the song stored in the .mp3 file. Internally, this information is stored in a tag (most commonly an ID3v2.3 tag) embedded in the .mp3 file. And by most commonly, I mean 99.9% of the time. The format of an .mp3 file is shown below:

You don't have to know any of the details about the low level format of an ID3v2.3 tag in order to use this class. You can simply open an .mp3 file, and then use the MP3 class's methods to get or set the information you want. You can set things like the name of the song, the track number, the name of the band who wrote the song, the lyrics to the song, the album the song was released on, store images of the CD cover, etc. all without knowing a single thing about ID3v2.3 tags. All of the details are handled for you. To see how easy the MP3 class is to use, look at the sample code shown below: 

 
 import com.beaglebuddy.mp3.MP3;
 import com.beaglebuddy.mp3.enums.PictureType;

 public static void main(String[] args)
 {
    try
    {
       MP3 mp3 = new MP3("c:/mp3/legions_of_hell.mp3");
       mp3.setBand("Axel Rudi Pell");
       mp3.setAlbum("Kings and Queens");
       mp3.setAudioDuration(520);         // 520 seconds == 8 minutes and 40 seconds
       mp3.setMusicType("(79)");          // 79 == Hard Rock
       mp3.setRating(200);                // 1= worst, 255 = best
       mp3.setTitle("Legions Of Hell");
       mp3.setTrack(6);
       mp3.setYear(2004);
       mp3.setLyrics("From the distance came the thunder\nAnd took their breath away\nEternal lights forever\n...");
       mp3.setPicture(PictureType.FRONT_COVER, new File("c:/images/axel_rudi_pell.kings_and_queens.jpg"));
       mp3.save();
    }
    catch (IOException ex)
    {
       System.out.println("An error occurred while reading the mp3 file.");
    }
 }

But, if you're an ID3v2.3 tag expert, and want to work directly with the tag itself, then you certainly can do that as well. Just call the MP3 class's getId3v23Tag() method in order to get direct access to the ID3v23Tag tag.

getMusicType

public java.lang.String getMusicType()
gets the category of music for this song.

Returns:
the music category for the type of music. If the type of music has not been specified, then null is returned.

setMusicType

public void setMusicType(java.lang.String type)
sets the category of music for this song.

References to the ID3v1, ID3v2, and WinAmp genres (which are shown in the list below) can be made by starting with an opening parenthesis "(" followed by a number from the genres list and ended with a closing parenthesis ")".
Example: (17) indicates "Rock"

This may optionally be followed by a refinement. The refinement can either be another music category from the list, or it may be text.
If the refinement is a music category from the below list, then the refinement should have two opening parentheses, as shown in the following example.
Example: (17)((79) indicates "Rock" with a refinement of "Hard Rock"

Otherwise, if the refinement is text, it can appear as in the example below.
Example: (4)Eurodisco indicates "Disco" with a refinement of "Eurodisco"

Parameters:

Returns:
the raw bytes comprising the image of the specified picture type.

getPictures

public java.util.Vector<ID3v23Frame> getPictures()
gets all the pictures stored in the .mp3 file's tag.

Returns:
a list of all the frames containing pictures in the .mp3 file's tag. If no pictures are found in the tag, then an empty list is returned.

getRating

public int getRating()
gets the rating of the song.

Returns:
the rating of the song. The rating is 1-255 where 1 is worst and 255 is best. 0 is unknown. If no song rating has been specified, then 0 is returned.

Parameters:
rating - the rating of the song where 1 is worst and 255 is best. 0 is unknown.
